sn22.87:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn22.87:1.2: Now at that time Venerable Vakkali was staying in a potter’s shed, and he was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.87:1.4: “Please, reverends, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him:
sn22.87:1.5: ‘Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is sick, suffering, and gravely ill. He bows with his head to your feet.’
sn22.87:1.7: ‘Sir, please go to the mendicant Vakkali out of compassion.’”
sn22.87:1.8: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They did as he asked.
sn22.87:2.1: Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robes, went to Venerable Vakkali.
sn22.87:2.2: Venerable Vakkali saw the Buddha coming off in the distance and tried to rise on his cot.
sn22.87:2.3: But the Buddha said to him,
sn22.87:2.4: “It’s all right, Vakkali, don’t get up.
sn22.87:2.5: There are some seats spread out, I will sit there.”
sn22.87:2.6: He sat on the seat spread out and said to Vakkali,
sn22.87:2.7: “I hope you’re keeping well, Vakkali; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
sn22.87:2.8: “Sir, I’m not all right, I’m not getting by. My pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is apparent, not its fading.”
sn22.87:2.9: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”
sn22.87:2.10: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”
sn22.87:2.11: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
sn22.87:2.12: “No sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
sn22.87:2.13: “In that case, Vakkali, why do you have remorse and regret?”
sn22.87:2.14: “For a long time I’ve wanted to go and see the Buddha, but I was physically too weak.”
sn22.87:3.1: “Enough, Vakkali! Why would you want to see this rotten body?
sn22.87:3.2: One who sees the teaching sees me.
sn22.87:3.3: One who sees me sees the teaching.
sn22.87:3.4: Seeing the teaching, you see me.
sn22.87:3.5: Seeing me, you see the teaching.
sn22.87:4.4: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn22.87:4.6: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
sn22.87:4.7: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
sn22.87:4.18: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’”
sn22.87:5.1: And then, after giving Venerable Vakkali this advice, the Buddha got up from his seat and went to the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn22.87:5.2: Then Venerable Vakkali addressed his carers,
sn22.87:5.3: “Come on, reverends, lift my cot and take me to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.
sn22.87:5.4: It’s unthinkable for one like me to die in an inhabited area!”
sn22.87:5.5: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants, and did as he asked.
sn22.87:5.6: Meanwhile, the Buddha spent the rest of that night and day on Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn22.87:5.7: Then, late at night, two glorious deities, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.
sn22.87:5.9: “Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is intent on liberation!”
sn22.87:5.10: And another deity said to him,
sn22.87:5.12: This is what those deities said.
sn22.87:5.13: Then they bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right side, before vanishing right there.
sn22.87:6.1: Then, when the night had passed, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn22.87:6.2: “Come, mendicants, go to the mendicant Vakkali and tell him:
sn22.87:7.1: ‘Vakkali, hear the word of the Buddha and two deities.
sn22.87:7.2: Late last night, two glorious deities, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and stood to one side.
sn22.87:7.4: “Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is intent on liberation!”
sn22.87:7.5: The other deity said to him,
sn22.87:7.10: Your death will not be a bad one; your passing will not be a bad one.”’”
sn22.87:7.11: “Yes, sir,” those monks replied. They went to Vakkali and said to him:
sn22.87:7.12: “Vakkali, hear the word of the Buddha and two deities.”
sn22.87:8.2: “Please, reverends, help me off my cot.
sn22.87:8.3: It’s unthinkable for one like me to listen to the Buddha’s instructions sitting on a high seat.”
sn22.87:8.4: “Yes, reverend,” replied those mendicants, and helped him off his cot.
sn22.87:8.5: They repeated what the Buddha had said.
sn22.87:8.14: Vakkali said, “Well then, reverends, in my name bow with your head at the Buddha’s feet. Say to him:
sn22.87:8.15: ‘Sir, the mendicant Vakkali is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
sn22.87:8.16: He bows with his head to your feet.’
sn22.87:8.19: I have no doubt of that.
sn22.87:8.20: I’m certain that what is impermanent is suffering.
sn22.87:8.21: And I’m certain that I have no desire or greed or fondness for what is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.
sn22.87:8.32: I have no doubt of that.
sn22.87:8.33: I’m certain that what is impermanent is suffering.
sn22.87:8.34: And I’m certain that I have no desire or greed or fondness for what is impermanent, suffering, and perishable.’”
sn22.87:8.35: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied, and left.
sn22.87:8.36: And then, not long after those mendicants had left, Venerable Vakkali slit his wrists.
sn22.87:9.1: Then those mendicants went up to the Buddha and told him Vakkali’s message.
sn22.87:10.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
sn22.87:10.2: “Come, mendicants, let’s go to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili,
sn22.87:10.3: where Vakkali, the gentleman, slit his wrists.”
sn22.87:10.5: Then the Buddha together with several mendicants went to the Black Rock on the slopes of Isigili.
sn22.87:10.6: The Buddha saw Vakkali off in the distance lying on his cot, having cast off the aggregates.
sn22.87:11.1: Now at that time a cloud of black smoke was moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between.
sn22.87:11.2: The Buddha said to the mendicants,
sn22.87:11.3: “Mendicants, do you see that cloud of black smoke moving east, west, north, south, above, below, and in-between?”
sn22.87:11.5: “That’s Māra the Wicked searching for Vakkali’s consciousness, wondering:
sn22.87:11.7: But since his consciousness is not established, Vakkali is extinguished.”
